normalised: Okay, folks, let's be real. How many of you just groaned internally when the lights flickered and died? Load shedding – that dreaded phrase we hear all too often, especially during those scorching Delhi summers or right before Diwali when everyone's got their fairy lights blazing. It's back, and it's not making anyone happy.

normalised: Basically, load shedding is when the power company, like, say, Tata Power in Mumbai or even the local electricity board in a small town near Patna, deliberately cuts off electricity supply to certain areas for a specific period. Why? Well, usually it's because demand is higher than the supply. Imagine everyone in your mohalla cranking up their A C s to beat the heat, and the poor transformers just can't cope. Bang! Load shedding.

normalised: The thing is, load shedding is a huge pain. You're in the middle of binge-watching your favorite web series (Sacred Games, anyone?), studying for that crucial engineering exam at I I T Kanpur, or even just trying to make a decent biryani for the family. Suddenly, poof, darkness. And the fridge starts making those sad, melting-ice noises. It's the worst.

normalised: Of course, there are reasons. Sometimes it's a legitimate infrastructure problem. Maybe a cable got damaged by the monsoon rains in Kerala, or a generator at a power plant in Chattisgarh broke down. Other times, it's just plain mismanagement and not enough investment in upgrading the power grid. We need better infrastructure, more efficient power generation, and maybe even a national awareness campaign on energy conservation. Remember those "Save Electricity" ads from Doordarshan back in the day? Maybe it's time to bring them back!

normalised: And it's not just inconvenient; it affects businesses too. Imagine a small textile factory in Tirupur losing hours of production because of load shedding. Or a software company in Bangalore having to rely on expensive generators to keep the servers running. It impacts the economy, small and big.

normalised: So, what can we do? Well, conserving energy is a good start. Switch to L E D bulbs, use appliances wisely, and maybe think twice before cranking the A C down to sixteen degree Celsius. More importantly, we need to hold our elected officials accountable and demand better planning and investment in our energy infrastructure. Load shedding shouldn't be a way of life in the twenty first century, especially not in a country aiming to be a superpower!
